title: Myths and Believes
common: Among the many talks I had with genealogist Gilber Rubim Rangel, author of various historical books (Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário de Genealogia ; Rangel, Gilber Rubim, Dicionário de Genealogia, Instagram ; Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário Histórico-Geográfico do Estado do Espírito Santo), some pages of the books are accessible on the Archive website (Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário de Genealogia ; Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário Histórico), one particularly inspired the creation of this section. We discussed the different myths that have been, and still are, created to shape our ancestors into the characters we desire (Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário de Genealogia, pp. 262 - 264).

Genealogy is not the only area of history where myths and beliefs are created; many historical events have been taught in their mythological versions, as recent research shows. To help readers better understand these beliefs and myths, we have cataloged brief descriptions below. By clicking on the links, you will be directed to pages where you can expand your knowledge about them and discover the facts behind these myths.
The myths can be updated at any time based on new research.

value.name: Is it possible to trace a genealogical tree back to the first humans?
value.desc: Studying the past is a challenge. As we delve further back in time, documentation becomes scarce, and myths often intertwine with facts. It is common to find connections tracing back to a supposed first ancestor suggested by writers. However, the evolution of knowledge shows that there are over 7,000 generations between the invention of writing and these early ancestors.

value.name: Relationship between the Banu Qasi and the Arabs:
value.desc: Various studies have suggested that some members of the Banu Qasi might be descendants of Musa ibn Nusair and the prophet Muhammad. However, there is no known documentation to support these claims (Medieval Lands, , Moorish Spain). Often, hypotheses are taught as facts to support desired connections.

value.name: Who claimed that indigenous peoples are inherently different?
value.desc: I've noticed a tendency among some individuals to marginalize others or perceive themselves as superior based on personal preferences or the echo chambers they inhabit. But is there any factual basis for this notion of superiority? Having made similar errors myself, whether it was celebrating a sports victory or receiving misguided teachings, I've included research here that aims to address this question from a technical standpoint, both concerning indigenous peoples and the broader population.

value.name: Are European kings descendants of the Visigoths?
value.desc: There is an attempt to create a continuous lineage between kings of different empires and civilizations. However, when it comes to the Visigoths, they should be considered in isolation. It is important to explicitly state that connections to them are largely hypothetical.

value.name: Who truly discovered America (Abya Yala)?
value.desc: While this question may seem straightforward and readily answered in history books, it's essential to recognize the limitations of solely adhering to one worldview.

value.name: In the past, the firstborn children were named after their parents:
value.desc: This argument is often used to create connections and extend genealogical trees, but it faces the problem that this practice was not always followed. For example, the genealogy of the Kings of León shows instances where this tradition was not maintained.

value.name: Was there a Sumerian Flood?
value.desc: There is much confusion about the relationship between science and beliefs. In this text, we aim to show that science does not seek to destroy beliefs; rather, it helps us better understand what ancient texts convey.
